text: So here's. Here's how we. We all enter the world. We start life as a little blob of chemistry and physics. It's a little unfertilized oocyte. The. Then there's this incredibly magical process called embryogenesis, where slowly and gradually there's never a magic lightning flash that takes you from physics to the land of psychology. But what happens is eventually you become one of these beings that are susceptible to the tools of behavioral science or maybe even psychoanalysis and something like this. And so the story of our origin is really the story of scale scaling up, of cognition and transformation. It's really, as scientists and philosophers, we need to understand this transformative process of how mind emerges from these simpler components. In fact, if you look at an early embryonic blastoderm, there might be a couple of hundred thousand cells at some particular stage. And you look at that and you say, well, there's an embryo. When you say it's an embryo, what are you counting? What is there one of? There's hundreds of thousands or millions of cells. Well, it turns out that the best thing you could say is that what there is one of is commitment to a particular story.
primary_topics: Transformation of simple components to complex organisms
content_summary: The presentation discusses the transformation process from an unfertilized oocyte to a complex organism through embryogenesis. It emphasizes the emergence of cognition and the concept of cellular commitment in this transformative process.
